Posts.Content: May 13, 2008 08:51PM - edited May 13, 2008 08:52PM by larousse Tammy, so sorry, it is a horrible moment for you to be in. But you found the right place. There are many here who have been in your shoes and will be able to help you. You can only take on this thing one step at a time once you are over the initial shock. Were there any details in the biospy results? that may help the people here to give you more info on what is the standard treatment. Surgery asap sounds good. The sooner you know exactly what stage it is, the sooner you will be able to start the appropriate treatment. Keep posting, you will get a lot of support in this place. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 08:07AM larousse wrote: As Leaf described, beware of false positive, I was warned about it, but it still brought extra concerned in my case. I had an MRI after biopsy and before lumpectomy to make sure there wasn't anything else in either breast. The problem was that it showed some suspicious lesions (large according to the docs) and had to have a larger excesion as a result. It turned out that the suspecious lesion was begnin, fibrocystic stuff. It appears that it is very common to get false positive with an MRI.
Posts.Title: breast mri Carly68 twink

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 10:15PM larousse wrote: My humble comment: my surgeon's rational for not doing the partial breast rads, which I decided to acknowledge, is that the ducts are long enough that there could be only 1 little C cell astray, too far from the site to get hit by the radiation that could turn into a recurrence. Although most recurrence are in the same location as the original area, there is a high enough % of recurrence that are somewhere else in the breast. I would do a lot of research on this, before making that choice. The biggest advantage is time, but in the long run, 6 weeks goes by rather quickly, and you don't get to be in a study. I wanted to know the stats of the treatment. The onc who was promoting this had some vague positive statement without real numbers, you may have better numbers than me. There are some on this site who did it and may come along to give their opinions and describe SE. Good luck in making your decision. I found that we have a lot of decisions to make with all the tx choices and it is nerve wracking.
Posts.Title: PBI choice - baloon insert or 3D external beam ftreloar CherylRubie

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 01:16AM larousse wrote: Hello there, how is the weather in the UK? I am not an expert but from my own research concerning my case, and if you use stats to make your decision (some people go with gutt feelings rather than numbers), radiation decreased my odds of getting a recurrence in half. I haven't needed chemo, but from what I have heard it is a breeze compare to chemo. There is some SE and the slight change of getting other problems but those were small % compare to my odds of getting a recurrence. The numbers helped me making my decision. Good luck in this difficult time.
Posts.Title: Radiation Trial sueps LUVmy2girlZ

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 08:09PM larousse wrote: SJacques, I have been diagnosed with the same thing at the same time as you. Had surgery on 1/10. I am also nervous about the radiation which I am starting tomorrow, 33 treatments, but today I saw the rad onc and drilled him again with my concerns. I asked him, if it was his wife with dcis, would he recommend mastectomy or rads. Well, I surprised to find out that his wife had dcis at age 40, grade 3, and did the rads. I have talked with quiet a few women, including on these, who have gone through this and moved on with their lives. He also told me about a woman with low grade, who decided not to do the rads, well it came back, invasive after 4 years. You are on the right path, hang in there, visit the April radiation thread, you can share your concerns, problems, etc. This is a great support system, and you will be done soon and move on, like so many. You should ask your doc for some anti-anxiety for night time, it helps me when I am getting all angst up.

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2008 11:09PM larousse wrote: Hi all, I asked my rad onc about IMRT after hearing about it and I was pissed that it isn't what they are doing with my breast. But, he explained to me that they make the machine perform (by some settings) so that it actually works like IMRT. He said that IMRT is very expensive (like $75,000 isn't?), it isn't reimbursed by insurance for the right breast treatment. Basically the performance is the same as an IMRT treatment. I don't know if that made any sense. I found that I don't get info on anything unless I drill with questions. It is too bad, they could definately benefit from a little marketing, I guess it would cost them a few seconds of explanations. Sorry just a little irritaded with that mode, don't tell unless asked, rant...rant...

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 11:54AM - edited Apr 25, 2008 11:54AM by larousse Ditto to juliajo's comment. I am also a April rad gal, just passed the halfway point (14 left out of 33), doing okay, working, exercising, cooking good food for the family, etc. My skin is pink since #8, but it hasn't gotten a lot worst since then. There are all kinds of good creams out there. It isn't a complete breeze but it isn't horrible, right now anyway. I was concerned about shrinkage, doc extend tx by 3 days, less intensity daily is suppose to help, no shrinkage yet. I also had DCIS... my onc saw some invasive recurrence, from dcis to stage 1 or 2 on women who didn't do the rads. He convinced me that it was the right thing to do. Good luck in making these though decisions, I still wonder if I should have taken everything off, time will tell...

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2008 09:57PM larousse wrote: DebiK, In my case, calcifications were how they diagnos my DCIS. In Situ (IS) is what you want to hear if you have breast cancer because it isn't invasive therefore not life threathening, however, the course of treatment is agressive as they want to prevent recurrence which could be invasive. DCIS is often treated with lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifen if it is hormone receptor positive. In many cases calcification are begnin. Lets hope for that. There is a thread somewhere on this site for DCIS. Best of luck. Larousse

Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 10:40AM larousse wrote: I am feeling chatty this morning so I will add my 2 cents. Doe, I don't know if you are doing low fat because of BC, but if it is to loose weight, I find it impossible to live like that. My thing is good food, meals and portions. 3 yummy meals a day and afternoon snack, eat anything as long as portion are moderate and even small. So, I was raised in France and that the way the french eat, I am used to it but I don't think that it is very hard if you allow yourself to eat everything, including pasta and chocolate. If I gain a few lbs, I just eat the same as the dh and kids, just less on the plate. If I need to stuff myself, I try to do it veggies. So sorry about about the antidepressants and the hubby. My dh seems to think that sex is forbidden during rads, he got like that during my pregnancies also... hmm...

Posts.Content: larousse wrote: I finished radiation about a month ago. I was one of the lucky ones, didn't have too bad of a time with the treatment. I went back to lifting weights and sort of overdid it with the chest workout. Yesterday I started to have little shooting pains in the bad breast. They are very short but very noticeable. These don't feel like muscle soreness as they go away really quickly. I didn't have any nodes dissected, but of course I am worried about lymphedema. Could this be a symptom? or is it just the nerves that were cut then zapped? Did anybody else experienced that, a month post treatment? Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 08:43PM larousse wrote: Hi there, I think your are okay if you aren't using some lotion with sunscreen. Also, I have been using Biafine, it is a prescription cream used for burns. It is expensive but they had samples at the doc. They say not to use it a least 4hrs before tx. I start with pure Aloe right after tx, in the changing room, then apply Biafine 2-3 times a day. I noticed that the area missed by the aloe turns slightly pink immediately. So that must be really good stuff.
